title: The Pious Man, a prayer-poem by Mordecai Kaplan adapted from the essay "An Analysis of Piety" by Abraham Joshua Heschel (1942)
author: Aharon N. Varady (editing/transcription)

coauthors.name: Aharon N. Varady (editing/transcription)

coauthors.name: Mordecai Kaplan
coauthors.bio: Mordecai Menahem Kaplan (June 11, 1881 – November 8, 1983), was a rabbi, essayist and Jewish educator and the co-founder of Reconstructionist Judaism along with his son-in-law Ira Eisenstein.

coauthors.name: Abraham Joshua Heschel
coauthors.bio: Abraham Joshua Heschel (January 11, 1907 – December 23, 1972) was a Polish-born American rabbi and one of the leading Jewish theologians and Jewish philosophers of the 20th century. Heschel, a professor of Jewish mysticism at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, authored a number of widely read books on Jewish philosophy and was active in the civil rights movement.

excerpt: "The Pious Man" is a prayer-poem from Mordecai Kaplan's diary entry, September 19, 1942, on the virtue of piety as expressed in an essay published earlier that year by Abraham Joshua Heschel. Piety was a Roman virtue, but in this essay, A.J. Heschel appears to be describing an idealization of Ḥasidut. . . .
